Author: jkush
Title: Ask News.YC: How much time and effort do you spend on SEO techniques to gain traffic?
Content:
...and if you've had successes in the past what did you do? Did you hire an SEO firm or do it yourselves?

I've got a startup that's facing a fair amount of keyword competition. Ranking in search engines is going to take some time. Purchasing advertisements is possible, but our budget is limited. Any advice?

Author: jkush
Content: Nice post Sam. I wonder about #1, though. How do you tell the difference between when you think your company is dying and when it really is?

Author: bayareaguy
Content:
AWS would charge you about $1 million a month to load and store 1 petabyte, which sounds good until you realize that Google also has several hundred thousand processors.

If you only needed 100,000 small EC2 instances, that would cost you at least $10 million a month.

Now suppose you need 1,000 managers and engineers to deliver all the same services. If the average cost is $10k/month each that's another $10 million a month.

So even with some pretty naive assumptions, the storage cost is less than 5% overall.

GOOG's own 2007 statement ( http://www.google.com/intl/en/press/pressrel/revenues_q107.h... ) says their operating expenses were closer to $1B for the full year, which is about 4x this. It also says they have closer to 12k full time employees.

Given that http://glinden.blogspot.com/2008/01/mapreducing-20-petabytes... claims to be doing 20PB MapReduce jobs, they obviously need a lot more than 5PB.

Still I bet their storage component is a lot closer to 1% of the total operating costs.

Author: nickb
Content:
Sam, thanks for an awesome post!

I have one question. You say the following:

>>> Figure out what the important things are, and spend lots time on those and little on the rest. Lots of startups work very hard, but on the wrong things.

Product is number one, no question about it. What else do you consider important and what do you consider 'wrong things'?

Content:
> Fail. Is this supposed to be a joke?

Don't think so; it's entertaining and shows actual working code that progresses over time such that a reader can see how basic concepts work.
